awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Computationally Aware Cyber-Physical Systems
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we generated new fundamental science for cyber-physical systems (CPSs).  The new science establishes the foundations of Computationally Aware Cyber-Physical Systems, opening a new multidisciplinary research direction.  Via a new modeling and hybrid control approach, accurate and robust tracking control of CPSs is now possible in real-world testbeds.  Specifically, the algorithms developed with the new tools that include prediction schemes exploiting computational capabilities to arrive at more accurate predictions, within the time constraints.  Over its life, this collaborative award supported multiple graduate students and postdocs, and lead to numerous publications in book collections, journals, and conference venues.  The results from this project were disseminated to the technical community, in particular, via workshops and visits to partners (domestic and international), and to the broad community, via internships and social media. In particular, the effort in this project lead to the new Northern California Workshop on Nonlinear Control in 2018 and 2019. It also lead to a MOOC on modeling and simulation of cyber-physical systems. This MOOC uses the modeling techniques developed in this project and conveniently applies it to the modeling of physics, algorithms implemented in computing platforms (the cyber part), and the interfaces. This project trained numerous students and postdocs in the future research direction of his research group involving optimization, prediction, and feedback control for hybrid and cyber-physical systems.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2020
Modified by: Ricardo Sanfelice

por.por_txt_cntn:
In this project, we generated new fundamental science for cyber-physical systems (CPSs).  The new science establishes the foundations of Computationally Aware Cyber-Physical Systems, opening a new multidisciplinary research direction.  Via a new modeling and hybrid control approach, accurate and robust tracking control of CPSs is now possible in real-world testbeds.  Specifically, the algorithms developed with the new tools that include prediction schemes exploiting computational capabilities to arrive at more accurate predictions, within the time constraints.  Over its life, this collaborative award supported multiple graduate students and postdocs, and lead to numerous publications in book collections, journals, and conference venues.  The results from this project were disseminated to the technical community, in particular, via workshops and visits to partners (domestic and international), and to the broad community, via internships and social media. In particular, the effort in this project lead to the new Northern California Workshop on Nonlinear Control in 2018 and 2019. It also lead to a MOOC on modeling and simulation of cyber-physical systems. This MOOC uses the modeling techniques developed in this project and conveniently applies it to the modeling of physics, algorithms implemented in computing platforms (the cyber part), and the interfaces. This project trained numerous students and postdocs in the future research direction of his research group involving optimization, prediction, and feedback control for hybrid and cyber-physical systems.
